title: second wave hancock
story: The under-fire Health Secretary this morning expressed concerns over the number of cases in not just Europe but across the globe, and doubled down on warnings that everyone must continue to be cautious.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesHe was quickly blasted for scaremongering about a second Covid wave.Senior MPs accused him of acting like the “Grim Reaper” and warned his terrying rhetoric will leave Brits too spooked to leave their homes.They urged him to to use a “stiletto not a sledgehammer” to tackle fresh Covid outbreaks.  Appearing on Sky News, Mr Hancock vowed to do whatever it takes to stop the virus peaking again in Britain.He said: I am worried about a second wave. You can see a second wave starting to roll across Europe.We have to do everything we can to prevent it from reaching these shores.It’s not just Spain, there are other countries too where the number of cases is rising, and we are absolutely determined to do all we can to keep this country safe.Prime Minister Boris Johnson has also warned of a second coronavirus wave emerging in Europe as a -day quarantine for travellers ing from Spain was introduced to stop the spread of the bug.He said: Lets be absolutely clear about whats happening in Europe. Among some of our European friends, Im afraid you are starting to see in some places the signs of a second wave of the pandemic.But experts warned him not to overreact and force the country back into another lockdown.It comes as: Mr Hancock later erupted with fury on BBC Radio s Today programme after the host Nick Robinson suggested calling it a second wave was hysterical.He said: Im the Health Secretary in the middle of a global pandemic.So youll excuse me for being concerned about the health of the British people.That is absolutely at the front of my mind.So yes, you can see the increase in cases, you can see the sharp increase that we saw in Spain and hence we took the rapid action that we did.Furious MPs blasted his “loose language” and said he was wildly over-egging the danger.Senior Labour MP Chris Bryant stormed: “It makes me so angry that the government are so loose with their language. There isn’t a second wave rolling out across Europe.There are worrying signs of inidual spikes of increased infection in some areas. We need a stiletto not a sledgehammer to tackle this.New NHS figures today revealed just  people died from coronavirus in England.Ex-Tory leader Iain Duncan Smith said: “We have gone barking mad over Covid.“We have ministers acting like the Grim Reaper. We need a balanced message.”Gloom-laden messages about a second wave will put Brits off heading back to work and getting the economy moving again, Mr Duncan Smith warned.Ministers have become so “petried” of Covid they risk sparking an “economic Armageddon”, he added.England had the highest number of excess deaths in Europe during the coronavirus pandemic, new figures released today have shown.Although Spain had the biggest spike in excess mortality - deaths from all causes, not just coronavirus, above the five year average - England has had the longest continuous period with more deaths than usual.An interactive map by the Office for National Statistics shows the number of excess deaths across Europe and enables users to search by their local area.In the UK, Birmingham recorded the highest peak of any major British city with an excess mortality rate of . per cent. It was then followed by London and Manchester.The news came after a -day quarantine for travellers ing from Spain was introduced on Saturday, and more countries could soon be included.Eleven countries where air bridges exist with the UK have had a recent spike in cases, including Belgium, Luxembourg and Croatia.Brits are still able to travel to Luxembourg despite the country having the highest rate of coronavirus cases in Europe, almost  times higher per capita than Britain.However, Brits will be warned not to travel to Belgium and Luxembourg by the end of the week – throwing face-to-face Brexit talks in doubt.Belgium and Luxembourg will be chucked off the ‘air bridge’ list when the government review of the policy takes place on Friday.Belgium’s cases have shot up recently with . cases per ,, while Luxembourg’s infection numbers are at a huge . per ,.The UK’s rate is now at  per ,.Belgium’s removal from the list throws the next round of Brexit talks, which are due to take place in Brussels in three weeks on August .Tourists and the travel industry are in chaos after the surprise decision on Saturday night to change Foreign Office advice to advise people to stay away from Spain.Brits are now advised against all but essential travel to the country - with the Spanish islands now included too.Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden has insisted people can continue to book holidays but need to be aware of the risk that quarantine could be imposed.But as long as people are aware of that risk they should continue to book holidays, but just bear in mind that this may happen, and sadly it has happened in Spain, he told BBC Breakfast.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: law graduate plunged bridge dont leave me
story: Witnesses saw Azra Kemal, , escape her burning vehicle before falling ft from the dual carriageway in Kent, an inquest heard today. This reservation was not there. She was still alive. The guy jumped down and could not see her.She said Dont leave me here.Her last words were Please dont let me die. An inquest, which opened on Thursday by coroner Alan Blundson at County Hall in Maidstone, Kent, gave Azras cause of death as multiple severe injuries.The single graduate of Whetstone, North London was identied by police who were called to the scene shortly after .am on July .Mr Blunsdon said the occupants escaped after the vehicle caught fire by unknown means before witnesses travelling past saw two people on the carriageway approaching the central reservation..Azra then clambered over the central reservation and fell an approximate ft drop off the Medway Viaduct to the Haysden Country Park below.An off-duty nurse saw the car and called paramedics who attended - but Azra was pronounced dead at .am.The coroner added: She died in situ after medical intervention.Mr Blunsdon adjourned the inquest until .am on November  at County Hall, Maidstone.The tragedy happened on a two span bridge - known as the Medway Viaduct. She doted on me and I doted on her. title: mcdonalds fast food fans kfc instead coronavirus shut sandwell
story: Bosses have shut the West Midlands fast food outlet in Great Bridge, Sandwell, after the workers became infected amid a near ten-fold rise in local cases.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesA team in masks and medical outfits were seen outside the McDonalds this morning, with queues of customers later lining up outside KFC instead. Shoppers on the busy nearby high street said they would consider other fast food options after the outbreak.Mum Jane Timmons, , and her daughter Lexi, , regularly eat at the Great Bridge McDonalds.I didnt even know its closed, thats disappointing. I love a McChicken sandwich, Jane said.The staff in there are lovely andyou’ve got to wait too long they give you something extra. They all wore protective gear and were spraying everything so it’s surprising they’ve had an outbreak.” Lexi wasnt too worried, saying she and her mum would go to KFC instead.Plumber James Bancroft said he was coming for a McDonalds but turned into KFC instead.I didnt know anything about corona being here, he said.But I needed some food so KFC is just as good, they must be loving it being open with Maccies shut next door, he said.Leeann Taylor, , said she expected an exclusion zone around the restaurant.KFC is finger lickin good so I guess I dont careMcDonalds is shut, she said.I feel bad for the workers... Im glad Ive not got a Big Mac for a while though.Lexi Jones, , said she preferred to eat KFC anyway because she believed it contained fewer calories.I can get the mini fillets and its actually not that bad for calories,I even look at bread I blow up so I have to watch what I eat, she said.A McDonalds worker who wished to remain anonymous said he had been tested for coronavirus at the restaurant today.I don’t know who has tested positive, but it is worrying. We’ve had all the protective equipment so I don’t know how it’s happened, he said.Would-be customer Neil Hay, , was able to walk right into the quarantined takeaway without being stopped.He said: “They were quite rude actually, they said what are you doing here “I said I’ve just come for a burger and they told me to get out, we’re closed.“I said you should think about a sign and locking the door then.Business owner Adnan Ilyas, , said he was worried about another lockdown because of the outbreak.Before the coronavirus this road used to be really busy, and since lockdown it’s getting better again. But I’m worried we’ll have people scared to come out again, he said.Ex-biology lab worker Sheridan Hutchison, , said she was terried about strict restrictions being re-introduced.My family live round here and Ive not seen them since lockdown becuase we have dferent bubbles, she said.I think theres going to be more spikes and the virus is going to come back this winter as well.Madeleine Hickman, , said she had recently retired from working at an ASDA near the McDonalds.I know the staff in ASDA are very worried, I still speak to the girls and theyve been told to wear masks, she said.People would go to the McDonalds and then ASDA so Im worried it has spread.Following a dramatic surge in Covid- cases over the past week public health bosses warned the borough was halfway to a local lockdown.Positive cases have now rocketed to almost ten times the rate of last month with Sandwell now suffering the seventh highest number of weekly infections in the UK, . cases per , people.The council has set up its own contact tracing team to battle the spread of the disease.Ninety people have tested positive in the past seven days with Dr Lisa McNally, Sandwells director of public health, warning the next few weeks are crucial.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dog shelter massacre tunisia
story: The English owners of Le refuge Terrabella à Djerba, a rescue centre on the idyllic island of Djerba, say a heartless gang of three men broke in on the night of July  and mercilessly tortured the creatures.Shocking pictures show the extent of the animal’s injuries, with nails stuck into the dog’s eyeballs, several force-fed bleach, and mums and puppies beaten to death.Horried volunteers say they found the carcasses of dogs and barely alive, mutilated bodies of pups lying in a pool of their own blood.The perpetrators were reportedly detained by cops, but have since been released, it is alleged.A total of  dogs were killed in the sickening massacre, with several others escaping the mob and fleeing across the island.Hero rescuers from Rescue Animals North Africahelped to transport around  of the dogs to safety in the capital of Tunis, while other volunteers comb the island looking for the escaped strays.Since the attack, the shelter’s owners have reportedly been the target of further harassment - having escaped to safety across the island and rented a new site to help house the remaining dogs.They say they have been subject to verbal attacks and death threats.Florence Heath from RANA said: “Last night they were chanting death to dogs and death to foreigners [outside the owner’s home].“Florence said the attitude to dogs in the country is due to a “lack of education.”“They see them as vermin, equivalent to rats,” she added.The charity worker said the reason the shelters exist in the first place is to save pups from a cull around tourist season, where “cleansing vans” head to the streets to shoot stray dogs.Florence added it’s “hard to precipitate” what caused the sudden surge in violence against dogs.She said: “Potentially being in lockdown might have given them to focus on their grievances.“They were hard hit after the [ Sousse terror] attacks, and now this.”You can donate to the relief fund here, or head to RANAs website to find out how you can adopt Tunisias poor pups.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: 2 step testing plan arrivals matt hancock
story: The Health Secretary said scientists were looking at how to reduce the quarantine down from  days with additional testing.⚠️ Read our coronavirus live blog for the latest news  updatesIt could involve a two-step plan to test people at the border and again after several days in isolation, he said.Testing people once when they come in isnt good enough, as it wont catch people who may have got the bug but havent yet got signs or symptoms of it, he said.Speaking to BBC Breakfast this morning he explained: We are working on whether testing people during that quarantine, whether it is safe to be able to release them earlier.The quarantine period could be reduced down to as low as eight daysa person has a test several days into their isolation period which then comes back negative.Tests could also take place at the border to catch some positive cases too, he admitted.It comes as:Mr Hancock told the Beeb: The problem with this testing at the border problem is that you can incubate this disease for many days without displaying any symptoms and that wouldnt show up in a test.If the test comes back negative, you could have it but it just be incubating.You have to isolate anyway, so it doesnt make any dference to how people would behave.I am not against testing immediately when you get back but there is no positive purpose to it.If you test people sometime after they get back, can that reduce the level of quarantine  That is a scientic question on which we are doing the work.Mr Hancock stressed nothing would be changing in the next few days - and  days would be the required quarantine period for the time being.And it was better to keep the country safe and stop a second wave of the virus being imported from Europe.The Health Secretary this morning expressed concerns over the number of cases in not just Europe but across the globe.r Hancock vowed to do whatever it takes to stop the virus peaking again in Britain.He said: I am worried about a second wave.You can see a second wave starting to roll across Europe.We have to do everything we can to prevent it from reaching these shores.Its expected that later today officials will say that anyone who fears they have coronavirus will have to isolate for ten days - up from seven currently.People living with anyone with symptoms will still have to remain inside for a total of  days.Boris Johnson issued a warning this week as Covid- continues to spread across the continent.Lets be absolutely clear about whats happening in Europe. title: meghan markle pays 67000 legal costs
story: The Duchess of Sussex is suing Associated Newspapers Limitedover an article which reproduced parts of a handwritten letter sent by her to her dad Thomas Markle in August .⚠️Read our Meghan and Harry blog for the latest news on the Royal couple.ANL, publisher of the Mail on Sunday and MailOnline, won the first skirmish in the legal action on May , when Mr Justice Warby struck out parts of Meghans claim.This included allegations that the publisher acted dishonestly by leaving out certain passages of the letter.Court papers now show Meghan, , has agreed to pay ANLs £, costs for that hearing in full.The duchess is now awaiting a High Court ruling on a bid to keep secret the identities of five friends who gave an anonymous interview to a US magazine in her legal action against ANL.Meghans lawyers have applied for the five friends who gave an interview to People magazine to remain anonymous.In an article published by People in February of last year, the friends spoke out against the bullying Meghan said she has faced, and have only been identied in confidential court documents.The duchess says her friends gave the interview without her knowledge, and denies a claim made by ANL that she caused or permitted the People article to be published.Her legal team attended the High Court in London on Wednesday for a preliminary hearing before Mr Justice Warby in a bid to keep the identities of the friends secret.Lawyers for ANL are resisting the application, claiming the duchesss friends brought the letter sent by her father into the public domain when it was referred to for the first time in the People interview.In court documents for the hearing, Meghans lawyers argued that the friends - referred to as A to E - have a right to anonymity both as confidential journalistic sources and under their own privacy rights.Justin Rushbrooke QC, representing the duchess, said in written submissions to the court: To force the claimant, as the defendant urges this court to do, to disclose their identities to the public at this stage would be to exact an unacceptably high price for pursuing her claim for invasion of privacy against the defendant in respect of its disclosure of the letter.On her case, which will be tried in due course, the defendant has been guilty of a flagrant and unjustied intrusion into her private and family le.Given the close factual nexus between the letter and the events leading up to the defendants decision to publish its contents, it would be a cruel irony were she required to pay that price before her claim has even been determined.Mr Rushbrooke said that the publisher had made the interviews with People relevant to the case and had forced the duchess to identy the names of the five friends in a court document.Meghans lawyers also argue that ANL has already demonstrated a willingness to publish articles based on the contents of court documents.Mr Rushbrooke added: There can be little doubt that, in addition to defending this case through the courts, the defendant is seeking to maximise the publicity surrounding this case, which it has repeatedly dubbed the trial of the century. The barrister said there is ample evidence before the court to support his clients application to maintain the anonymity of her five friends.In a witness statement submitted earlier in July as part of the application, Meghan said: Each of these women is a private citizen, young mother, and each has a basic right to privacy.Both the MoS and the court system have their names on a confidential schedule, but for the MoS to expose them in the public domain for no other reason than clickbait and commercial gain is vicious and poses a threat to their emotional and mental wellbeing.The MoS is playing a media game with real lives.Mr Justice Warby said he will give his decision on the duchesss application in writing at a later date.Meghan is suing ANL over five articles, two in the MoS and three on MailOnline, which were published in February  and reproduced parts of a handwritten letter she sent to her father in August .The headline on the article read: Revealed: The letter showing true tragedy of Meghans rt with a father she says has broken her heart into a million pieces.The duchess is seeking damages from ANL for alleged misuse of private information,infringement and breach of the Data Protection Act.ANL wholly denies the allegations, particularly the duchesss claim that the letter was edited in any way that changed its meaning, and says it will hotly contest the case.Our journalists strive for title: prince harry travel industry green travel
story: The Duke of Sussex, , who is worth around £million and enjoys taking private jets, today called for more green travel - just as TUI announced plans to shut  high street shops sparking hundreds of job losses.⚠️Read our Meghan and Harry blog for the latest news on the Royal couple.While thousands across the travel industry worry about losing their jobs, Harry chose to lecture workers about the need for eco-friendly travel.The travel industry is desperately trying to survive after being rocked by Covid-, with TUI the latest major brand to fall victim today.EasyJet, British Airways and Ryanair are also cutting thousands of jobs, while plane manufacturer Airbus is axing , jobs at its two UK factories.Prince Harry said “businesses are hurting signicantly” with some “struggling to put food on the table”.But instead of addressing widespread job losses and financial ruin across the global industry, he chose to call for environmentally-friendly travel.He insisted the air industry needs to “build back better” in a “responsible” way – focusing around greener ways of travelling.Harrys advice comes despite the fact he has been routinely criticised for his own carbon footprint, with his and Meghans reportedly at around  times that of the average Brit.The Duke made the comments in the opening speech at a virtual global summit for his sustainable tourism project Travalyst.His speech came after claims were published at the weekend about his le, including allegations that he was angered by what he perceived to be his brother the Duke of Cambridges snobbish attitude towards Meghan.In the book Finding Freedom, serialised by the Times and the Sunday Times, the authors claimed relations between the Sussexes and the Cambridges grew so bitter that by March the couples were barely speaking.The duke, who now lives in Los Angeles with Meghan and their son Archie after the couple stepped down as working royals, said in his opening speech: Many of you joining us today rely on visitors for your livelihoods.Businesses are hurting signicantly, and Ive heard from some of you who are currently struggling to put food on your familys tables and make ends meet because there are no tourists and therefore no income.We need to build back - but we need to build back better. And that means theres a responsibility, a responsibility we cannot avoid or dismiss, for us to reshape this industry in a way that benefits everyone and everything for decades to come.Harry launched Travalyst last autumn, co-founding it with leading brands Booking, Skyscanner, Tripadvisor, Trip and Visa, and it now operates as an independent non-profit organisation based in the UK.Speaking on video-link, the duke went on to say: Before the pandemic unfolded we witnessed more and more young people expressing an interest in authentic travel experiences and an ability to partake in trips that are greener, that allow them to support local communities, uphold heritage and protect destinations and cultures.This is the future of travel, and a future that Travalyst is here to support and catalyse.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: baby struggles breathe after catching
story: NewsBaby struggles to breathe after catching coronavirus despite parents not having itPresley Dowdall was rushed to intensive care immediately after being born because she was unable to breathe, only to test positive for the coronavirus two days laterShareCommentsByDanny RustSarah Lumley:,  JUL NewsRoxanne holding baby Presley for the first time " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA baby boy has become one of Britainaposs youngest Covid- survivors after testing positive for the deadly virus - at just two days old. Presley Dowdall was born on May  at .pm, weighing lb oz. He was immediately rushed to the newborn intensive care unit , as he was unable to breathe. His mother Roxanne Dowdall was unable to see her son for over five hours after his birth. The -year-old did not get to hold him for the first time until four days later.  And she and husband Sam, , were left reeling when they got a call from the hospital two days after Presley was born - to let them know that the newborn had tested positive for coronavirus.Mum-of-two Roxanne, from Basildon, Essex, said: I couldnapost believe what I was hearing. It was such a shock. They phoned me up on the Wednesday evening, two days after Presley was born, and askedmy husband and I had had our Covid test results back yet.  Then they said, aposYou both tested negative, but Presley has tested positive. Weaposll see you tomorrowapos. It was just like that. I felt angry and guilty that I couldnapost protect my son, that I couldnapost even hold him. I also remember feeling embarrassed, like people would look at us dferently when I told them. I donapost think we will ever know how he could have got it. I had nothing that I could put my finger on to suggest that I could have passed it on to him.  I had so many questions about how he could test positive - but I think I just have to accept that we will never know. Thankfully, little Presley made a full recovery from the virus and is now happy and healthy at almost  weeks old. Roxanne, who is also mum to two-year-old Dixie, said that his birth was extremely dficult. She did not believe Presley was going to make it through his first night. Roxanne, who had to be induced in Basildon Hospital in Essex at  weeks, said: When theyaposre born, you wait for that first big cry - but I didnapost hear anything. He couldnapost breathe at all. The midwe that delivered him buzzed down to NICU straight away, and the doctors from NICU came up with the wires and the tubes and took him away.  The NICU ward was actually Covid-free until Presley was taken down there. He was born at .pm - but I didnapost get to see him until about .pm that night. It was very surreal, seeing him there with all the tubes, and the doctors doing all the stuff I should have been doing. It was like watching a movie. I knew he was mine, but it didnapost feel like he was mine. We hadnapost had a chance to get that bond. But just to know he was breathing was a good thing. Roxanne added that none of the staff that were on hand to deliver Presley were wearing masks or gloves.  She was told he was unlikely to have contracted it from them. Roxanne and Sam ed home without Presley the day after he was born. The mum had to deal with dficult questions from two-year-old Dixie about where her brother was. Thankfully, it was not too long before the parents could bring Presley home on Friday, May , four days after he was born. Roxanne said: I didnapost hold him for the first time until that day I brought him home. I went in to the ICU and he was still all intubated, and I didnapost even know how to pick him up. It was like he had the plague. The nurse asked meeverything was okay - she didnapost realise I hadnapost even held him yet.  She added: It was such a mix of emotions bringing him home. I so wanted him to come home with us, but I also had my daughter to think of - I didnapost want her to catch anything off him. But what with all the poorly babies in the NICU, it was actually safer to bring him home to quarantine there with us, than to leave him in the hospital. The first few days after bringing him home were really hard. I felt like I needed to be checking on him constantly - but then I felt really guilty for neglecting Dixie.

Scientists say the effect of lockdown is waning as hotspots of coronavirus infection hit many northern towns. It comes after the Government ordered anyone arriving from countries deemed high-risk to quarantine to stop them triggering new outbreaks. Oldham, Greater Manchester, has overtaken Leicester as the area with the second highest infection rate in England. The town had . cases for every , people in the seven days to July . Leicester’s has dropped to . and the Government is today expected to review its guidance on the lockdown imposed in late June.Blackburn with Darwen, Lancs, now has the highest infection rate in England, at . cases per ,. Restrictions have been imposed in Rochdale and Stockport, both in Gtr Manchester, and Wrexham, North Wales, due to new spikes. Wrexham currently has % of all Welsh infections the Army has been brought in to run Covid- testing centres. Prof Jose Vazquez-Boland, chair of infectious diseases at Edinburgh University, said: “We are facing a comeback of community transmission after removing the lockdown measures. The efficacy of lockdowns is only temporary. There will be a resurgence of new cases every time social restriction measures are lted as long as the virus remains in circulation.” Cambridge University’s MRC Biostatistics Unit estimates there are around , new infections a day in the UK. It put the R reproductive rate at near  in most regions. One expert saidinfection rates are not lowered we could face a second wave. Prof James Naismith. director of the Rosalind Franklin Institute in Oxford. said: “I fearwe fail to check this flare-up, we will head into winter with a high level of ­circulating virus. “With normal winter illnesses such as flu, we could see ato exponential growth in cases that overwhelms the NHS and requires complete lockdown. We have only a short time to get our systems ready to prevent this.” New NHS Test and Trace data will be released today but so far the system has only been reaching around a third of symptomatic cases. Confirmed cases are still low but increases were recorded each day last week for the first time since April.  Local authorities complain they are not getting detailed enough testing data in time to take action. Delayed test results also mean many contacts of those who test positive are not being told to self-isolate fast enough. Prof Naismith added: “The Government intervention that will make the most dference in keeping the lid on this flare-up is the isolation of positive cases. While parts of Italy and Spain recorded the highest peaks at points of the pandemic between February and June - England sustained the worst continuous death rates over that period, according to the analysis. Brentaposs excess deaths peak in the week ending  April was the worst rates in the UK during the crisis, the new Office for National Statisticsfigures out today show. The ONS calculated the figures by comparing the number of aposexcessapos deaths week by week, comparing them with year averages before the pandemic. The data also showed Birmingham was the city with the highest peak excess mortality overall at . per cent in one week, followed by Londonand Manchester . The map made available today allow people in England, Wales, Scotland, and Northern Ireland to check the mortality rates in their area over times. The visualisation allows the public to see how statisticians have compared UK death rates in local authority area, city and country levels, to those in other countries in Europe during the period. The ONS found the highest peak excess mortality was recorded in Madrid in Spain, at .% in the week ending April .  And of the four nations that make up the UK, England had the highest peak excess mortality  - at one point recording a high of .%. The ONS found England saw the second highest national peak of excess mortality during the week ending February  to week ending June , compared with  European countries. Only Spain saw a higher peak at the equivalent of local authority level. Areas of central Spain and northern Italy saw the highest peaks of excess mortality which surpassed any area of the UK.  The figures showed England had the highest peak of the four nations of .% during week  - the week ending April . This was followed by Scotland with a peak of .% during Week   - week ending April . Wales recorded its peak of .% during Week  - the week ending April . And Northern Ireland experienced the lowest peak, with .% during Week  - the week ending April . London, Birmingham and Manchester were the worst-hit in the UK. Edinburgh, Glasgow, Cardf and Belfast, the other major UK cities that the statisticians analysed, were not as hard hit, but still recorded excess deaths, peaking at %, .%, .% and .%, respectively. Epidemiologists say excess mortality - deaths from all causes that exceed the five-year average for the time of year - is the best way of gauging deaths from a disease outbreak because it is internationally comparable. The ONS analysis confirmed Britainaposs place as one of the countries worst hit by a pandemic that has killed more than , people worldwide. It says , more people than usual have died from all causes across the UK so far this year, the highest total in Europe.  Todayaposs figures showed the UK also had Europeaposs highest excess death rate when adjusted for the size and age of its population. The ONS explained the excess deaths were spread throughout the UK, in contrast to many European countries where they were concentrated in particular regions. Even so, England had a noticeably higher death rate than Scotland, which in turn had higher death rates than Wales and Northern Ireland. title: dr miriam stoppard ethnic minorities
story: NewsopinionDr Miriam Stoppard: Ethnic minorities being failed by lack of inclusive planningThe pandemic has starkly revealed that BAME people are less likely to use Covid- testing services – we need to look at issues from their point of view to find solutionsShareCommentsByMiriam Stoppard:,  JUL NewsopinionTesting kit instructions can be hard to understand for people whose first language is not English " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe longer the pandemic lasts, the more inequality we uncover.Now we learn both access to testing and its uptake is uneven across all socioeconomic groups, with BAME coming out worst. It’s not just in the UK that ­disparities exist – it’s worldwide. Action is needed to correct this so people from ethnic minorities are included in national and local health planning. Catherine Dodds of Bristol ­University and Ibidun Fakoya from King’s College, London suggest the way forward in an editorial in the BMJ. To keep the R number below one, governments are relying on ­nationwide testing and contact tracing until we have a vaccination programme in place. But while we wait, inequalities mean BAME Covid- infections and deaths keep rising.As Dodds and Fakoya point out we already know uptake of medical testing and screening is uneven across cancer risk assessment, antenatal screening, and HIV testing. The NHS is aiming to expand testing with self-administered swab kits – but this strategy may serve minority groups badly, bearing in mind a  UK study found uptake of HIV self-sampling kits among them was low compared with other groups. Most admitted they would probably not use the kits. Behind this reluctance were privacy issues and kits with complicated instructions that were inappropriately worded for people whose first language wasn’t English. Dodds and Fakoya emphasise until these faults are corrected it’s dficult to see how trust can be built up among our ethnic communities. Isn’t it time we looked at these ­disparities from the BAME point of view, and started framing instructions in a form that’s understandable, acceptable and useful for ethnic minorities instead of imposing a “one-size-fits-all” approach  Given the disproportionate and devastating impact this pandemic has already had among our ethnic minority communities, testing equality needs to be addressed in Covid- screening.

Health chiefs asked people who had been working or drinking at the Crown  Anchor in Stone, North Staffordshire, on July , , and  to get tested, after  positive cases were linked to the premises. The Crown and Anchor was closed last weekend to allow a risk assessment to be reviewed after an “overwhelming” number of visitors on Saturday, July . The crumbling former home is barely visible from the public footpath it sits alongside. But inside it has been left exactly as it was when the owner died approximately  years ago. Clothes still hang where they were drying over a wood-burning stove, opened food cans and jars are still rotting and family photos have remained still on display. Other items include a piano and a bed that was moved into the kitchen while teddy bears are sat on the dust-ridden chairs and he former occupantaposs glasses still sit on the bedside table. Richard Walden, , of Woolacombe, Devon, came across the cottage while walking with a friend on a public footpath in a rural location near Exeter on Tuesday evening. He said: I just stumbled across it and we were both like wow and we thought letaposs go and explore. One of the boards had been removed and the kitchen window was wide open so we took some photos inside. It was incredible. The house was literally untouched for about  years.It had clearly been lived in by an older person, probably a woman. There was still a tin of pilchards that hadnapost been emptied and the rotten remains of fish. There were lots of jars of food, marmite, and a woodburning stove. There was still wood in a bucket and hanging above was clothes that she had drying over the heat. The bed had been moved into the kitchen so it looks like in her final days she had been sleeping there. There were teddy bears placed in chairs, a couple of family member photos, and lots of books. You could see she was interested in art the countryside and birds.  But it was terribly sad. The cottage is so overgrown you could walk right past it and not notice anything. It is clearly a snapshot of someoneaposs le nearly  years ago. Presumably she sadly passed away and the house has been left since. It is a real time capsule. There is a clock, personal items lying around and her glasses still sit on the table next to the bed.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe prime suspect in the disappearance of Madeleine McCann tried to build a huge cellar at a second allotment in Germany. He dug stones out of a cellar under the allotment house and created a mound in his garden. This comes as police found a secret cellar at an allotment in Hanover,  miles from where this new site in Braunschweig is now in the spotlight. The lady now living in the allotment house told how she had been having nightmares that a body was hidden under the home where Christian Brueckner used to stay. Sabine Sellig, who bought the plot from Brueckner, has asked police to search and put her mind at rest.  A neighbour today claimed that Brueckner dug out a cellar at the bottom of the garden house near Braunschweig. Manfred Richter, , said: Brueckner excavated the floor of the house. He took out the rocks and the earth. He dug a big hole.  It was  metres deep and  m wide. He carried out the rocks and earth by hand and dumped it out by the front of the house. He put put planks of wood over the top of the hole. It took him two months to complete.  He started in the morning and worked until evening. Doing this work got him in trouble with the authorities in charge the gardens. Brueckner owned a house on the allotment from August  to April , while he ran a kiosk in the city,  miles from Hanover.  His first allotment in Hanover was excavated this week. Buildings on the site were demolished in late  or  but the cellar remained hidden. Neighbours told how he set up camp there in  - the year Madeleine disappeared. Neighbours in Braunschweig now believed this site will also be probed by police.  The woman who now owns the plot fears she could be sleeping above a body. Another owner of an adjoining garden in Braunschweig told reporters how Brueckner never seemed to do any gardening, but instead would work in his shed and spend time with his young girlfriend, Nakscije Mtari. This was before he suddenly disappeared. They referred to him as a strange man and would occasionally have a beer with him.  The allotment in Braunschweig is run by the local council and rented out to people. A small wooden house now stands at its entrance. Plot owners are allowed to construct small houses and stay overnight, but only sometimes. The plot is now covered over with grass, fruit trees, flowers and other plants while tools, a lawnmower and old bikes are littered about. The Mirror previously reported how the new owner of the land in Hanover fears he may have buried the body of a missing child known as the German Maddie there.  Brueckner was quizzed but never charged after Inga Gehricke, five, vanished in  near where he lived in Braunschweig. Today’s owner, a -year-old woman, said her fear stems from the allotment’s isolated location plus the fact that Brueckner was the tenant when tragic Inga went missing. And one of Brueckner’s old friends even suggested the possibility to her. The woman, a tour guide, told the Sunday People: “I am worried he may have buried a body here. I want the police to dig the ground and check.”  The woman added: “I don’t feel comfortable in the house now. I don’t knowI will stay living here.” A former Brueckner pal, who knows the woman, said: “There was a hole in the floor inside the allotment house and one day he told me he wanted to put a see-through perspex glass over it. “I said to him, ‘What the hell for  Just so you can look down into a dirty old cellar ’  “In retrospect I think he wanted to build a Fritzl cellar like the guy in Austria who put his daughter down there.” Madeleine McCann investigators have refused to say what they found in the secret cellar they discovered on Wednesday. Mini-diggers and forensic specialists with snfer dogs were seen in the garden and authorities were using large earth-moving machinery to dig up the entire backyard, according to local news reports. Several items were found in the Hanover cellar, under a shed which was demolished long ago.  They included plant pots, corrugated iron and a tree trunk, along with other items you might typically find at an allotment. Police have bagged up all the items and taken them away for inspection. Crime profiler and intelligence analyst Mark T. Hofmann has said police may not be solely focused on searching for a body. He said the police are likely looking for any form of data carrier - such as USB sticks, external hard drives or mobile phones. Nakscije Mtari, , is believed to have had an -month relationship with Brueckner when she was a teenager.  In June we reported how she was under police protection in a safehouse in Braunschweig. Police were watching her because she is a key witness in the case against her violent ex. Officers feared she could flee the country or may be attacked by one of Brueckner’s accomplices. Nakscije’s sister, mum-of-four Azra, said: “My sister is scaredChristian comes out now he could do her and us all harm... Christian always used to come over so nice to me.  “All of a sudden he changed and became very stressed. He and Nakscije went on vacation in ... When they came back she said ‘he hit me all the time’.” Brueckner is in jail for drug offences but has dropped his bid to be freed early, it was reported on Tuesday. He has also been sentenced to seven years for the rape of a woman on the Algarve in .  He is not serving that sentence at the moment because he is in the process of an appeal against the conviction, claiming his extradition was unlawful. A court hearing was told Brueckner is receiving “counselling” to deal with the media coverage and is now in solitary confinement to protect him from fellow prisoners. Brueckner regularly travelled between Portugal and Germany in his campervan, which could have easily been used to transport children without attracting attention.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe mum of tragic Hull student Libby Squire says her daughter remains a huge part of her family as they struggle to cope with her tragic loss. Libby disappeared from a bench in Hull on a bitterly cold February night in  - and was never seen alive again. Having been turned away from a local nightclub, she headed towards her home but never arrived. Tragically, on March , Libbyaposs body was recovered from the Humber Estuary, close to Spurn Point. Pawel Relowicz has been charged with her rape and murder. Minister Anne Dannerolle, of Hull Community Church, spoke to Lisa Squire on a video call this week. In that interview, Lisa explained how the family are coping. She said: “We are doing OK actually. It took a while to understand we would do this in our own way. “I am very much a crier, I cry at everything as my children will tell you, so I have obviously cried a lot.  “The children flitted in and out and did their own thing. My grief counsellor told me it is like when they are jumping in puddles, they just jump in and out. “That is what they do and with the age dference they act dferently. “We are getting through slowly. Some days are good and some days are bad. “But the five of us are really close. We stick together but we are still a unit of six but obviously just one is not here at the moment but we are plodding on slowly.”  When Libby disappeared there was huge support in Hull for her family and the police as they desperately searched for her. When her body was eventually found, there was an outpouring of grief across the city. That support and solidarity helped Libby’s family cope, Lisa explained. “We would just like to thank everyone for their love and support,” she said. “It really has helped. “When Libby was missing to know everyone was behind us and behind the police trying to find her was amazing. That really has helped to see strangers reaching out to you.  “I always feel really guilty because I didn’t actually get round to thanking everybody inidually but that was an enormous task and I’ve never been able to do it. “I am really grateful to everybody for their continued love and support.” Although  months has passed, Lisa says Libby remains a huge part of the family. “Libby is still very much part of our family,” she said, “and she never fails to put a smile on our faces when we think about her or remember her and her funny ways or some funny story one of the children tells. “Not many weeks back we were all sat in the garden and one of the children was saying remember when Libby did this, this or this. “The five of us were sat round the table laughing. It was like she was still here.  “We keep her as a very constant person in our family. Any cards, whether birthday or Christmas, gets signed from Libby as well because she is still part of our family and always will be. “We love her as much, maybe more than I did beforehand. We all miss her and that gets harder and harder every day. “But we know she is safe and that she is at peace. She is still a big presence. It was the same when she was here. She would say aposI’m number one, Mumapos and she still is. She is still my big girl. Mrs Dannerolle will say a few words at the small ceremony for the bench unveiling at .pm on Friday while the Lord Mayor Councillor Steve Wilson and ward councillors will also attend. The existing bench will be removed on Thursday.  Cllr Wilson said: “The tragic death of Libby affected the whole city and we hope this bench acts as a fitting tribute and somewhere people can come to remember her.” Lisa is delighted with the bench which will ensure Libby is never forgotten in Hull. “Thank you to turning that space into a lovely tribute to Libby,” she said. “I have only seen the photos and I’ve not been up to see it yet but it does look beautul. We are really grateful for that. “We are just really grateful for everything that everyone has done and I will come up to Hull and see the bench.”

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThree quarters of office workers think their employers could aposdo moreapos to address climate change and be more environmentally friendly. A study of , UK professionals, preparing to make their way back in to work, found  per cent get frustrated by a lack of consideration for the environment in the office. And four in  say this is a result of no one person having responsibility for driving green initiatives in the workplace. The research, by Go Ultra Low, revealed that despite these frustrations among professionals, three quarters of offices have recycling bins in a bid to be greener. Half have also removed single-use plastics from their workplaces, and  per cent have introduced energy-saving lightbulbs. But nearly a third of employees who drive want the option of an electric vehicleas a company car. Despite these measures, and more than half of office workers claiming to take care to recycle and save energy, a third admitted they are better at being green at home rather than at work. Poppy Welch, head of Go Ultra Low, said: Everyone is trying to be that little bit eco-friendlier at the moment, but it can be tricky when itaposs out of your hands. Employers have already made positive changes in the workplace to be more environmentally friendly, such as increasing access to recycling and energy saving measures, but itaposs evident that their employees are keen for more. There are a number of further changes businesses can make to be sustainable, including offering EV charging or switching company cars to EV models.  These can have multiple benefits, by helping the planet, giving employees a more positive outlook on the company and accessing cost savings due to lower running and maintenance costs for EVs. The study also found nearly a third of those polled would like the company they work for to install EV charging points. And  per cent would like to see EV carpooling or company cars introduced - given workplaces can access a subsidised scheme to have these installed. But  per cent believe budget constraints are holding back their employer from introducing greener initiatives, although recent changes by the government to Benefit-in-Kindtax could remove this barrier for EVs.  The changes to BIK tax means that EVs incur a  per cent tax rate, down from  per cent, enabling companies to provide an environmentally friendly company car, while saving money for both themselves and their employees. Just a quarter of professionals who drive a car knew of these changes, but once made aware nearly half were more likely to consider choosing an EV as a company car. Nearly three quarters agreed changes to BIK are a good idea to encourage people to switch to an EV, which are kinder to the planet and improves local air quality as they produce no tailpipe emissions. And  per cent thought employers should consider EV company cars as a result, with nearly two-thirds of respondents saying theyaposd like to drive an EV. The lower running costs - as low as p per mile -and environmental benefitswere cited as the primary factors that encourage them to drive an EV - according to the OnePoll data. Poppy Welch added: Thereaposs so much employers could do to make their businesses more sustainable, but it can be dficult to know where to start - especially when a number of measures require an upfront cost to implement. However, some are easier than others and with changes to Benefit-in-Kind taxes, employers and employees can make a financial saving while enhancing their companyaposs green credentials.

We need to build back - but we need to build back better. Before the pandemic unfolded we witnessed more and more young people expressing an interest in authentic travel experiences and an ability to partake in trips that are greener, that allow them to support local communities, uphold heritage and protect destinations and cultures. This is the future of travel, and a future that Travalyst is here to support and catalyse. Harry founded the Travalyst coalition, which is working to help tourists find more eco-friendly ways to travel. Heaposs often been accused of being hypocritical as he took a number of private jets last year.

story: NewsopinionAll the ways Eid al-Adha  will be dferent this year because of coronavirusEid al-Adha  will be celebrated with social distancing in place for the first time because of coronavirus - even the Hajj pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia may only see , pilgrims rather than the usual two million, writes Anila BaigShareCommentsByAnila Baig:,  JUL NewsopinionMuslim pilgrims pray at the Namira Mosque on Arafat Day, the climax of the Hajj pilgrimage, in Saudi Arabias holy city of Mecca " %, rgba, rgba, url"Get our daily coronavirus email newsletter with all the news you need to know direct to your inboxWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailLockdown may have eased but Muslims will be celebrating one of the holiest days in the Islamic calendar by continuing to observe social distancing rules. EID ul-Adha, which begins this evening and last four days, is celebrated across the globe, marks the culmination of the annual pilgrimage to Hajj and commemorates the sacrice made by the prophet Ibrahim, known as Abraham. But this year will be very dferent - even for the Hajj pilgrimage to Saudi Arabia where only , pilgrims are expected, rather than the usual two million. And Muslims in this country will also continue to make their own sacrices to avoid a second wave of coronavirus. President of the Bradford Council for Mosques, Zulfi Karim, said the community had done well to adapt to the new way of le. He knows first-hand how much Covid- can wreak havoc. He caught the virus in March and his symptoms developed rapidly, leaving him fearing he might die. He ended up in hospital and, several months on, he still experiences breathlessness when undertaking simple tasks and has lost his sense of taste and smell. He also caught pneumonia as a result of having Covid-. “It’s a very unpleasant illness and I still have the repercussions of it,” he said.  As representative of more than  mosques and madrassas in Bradford, Mr Karim also had to act quickly on the government’s advice to close all places of worship. Now the second Eid is here and faith centres have re-opened up with strict measures in place to enable worshippers to pray safely. Mr Karim said: “We are going to have hourly sessions with a limited number of people allowed in, they will bring their own prayer mats, wear masks and be placed a safe distance apart. “Covid- is still a threat to all sections of the community. I don’t want anyone to go through what I have been through.”  Usually Imam Alyas Karmani would be welcoming well over , worshippers for Eid prayers- especially as it falls on a Friday, the holiest day of the week, but not this year. Mr Karmani, who leads prayers at the Masjid Muhammadi on Lumb Lane, Bradford, said: “Rather than one prayer we will have three prayer times. I will be performing the khutbafrom behind a screen and all worshippers will sign in, wear masks and come with their own prayers mats. We have markers on the floor so people know where they can stand. We have signs and issued statements telling people they cannot hug or shake hands with each other.”  He said that anyone who had symptoms of coronavirus such as a cough or fever was not permitted in the mosque and elders and young children were also advised not to attend. “We are taking this very seriously. Faith centres have opened up but we need to be mindful we could well have a second wave so we want to ensure we keep people as safe as possible. “Some of us live in multi-generational homes and we want to be especially careful that we don’t increase the risk of passing on anything to our vulnerable elders.

story: NewsWoman kept diary entries detailing abuse before bodies found in freezerZahid Younis is on trial accused of murdering Henriett Szucs, , and Mihrican Mustafa, , and storing their bodies in a freezer in his Canning Town, east London, flatShareByNina LloydTalia ShadwellReporter:,  JUL NewsThe jury was told police found diary notes by Henriett Szucs torn up in the flat " %, rgba, rgba, url"News, views and top stories . You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailOne of two women whose bodies were found in the freezer of an east London flat had kept diaries detailing her abuse, a court has heard. The man accused of the womenaposs murders is alleged to have kept one of the womenaposs bodies in the freezer for as long as three years. Hungarian national Henriett Szucs, , vanished after moving in with accused murderer Zahid Younis, , and was last seen alive in the summer of . Her body was found in a small chest freezer in the Canning Town flat along with the remains of -year-old Mihrican Mustafa, who was last seen alive in May . The womenaposs corpses were discovered together during a police search on April , . Southwark Crown Court heard the women had both suffered appalling injuries including multiple broken ribs and Mihricanaposs sternum and larynx were also fractured. Henriett had been in the UK for several years and was last seen in Younisapos company in the summer of , jurors were told.  Mihrican, also known as MJ and Jan, struggled with drug addiction and homelessness and had also been spending time with Younis before she vanished in May , the court was told. The alleged double-murderer purchased the freezer with cash using a fake name for the sole purpose of hiding Henriettaposs body after she was killed on or before November , , the prosecution said. The court heard yesterday detectives discovered Henriettaposs diaries at the flat, and some of the entries allegedly detailed abuse at Younisapos hands. The remains of pyjamas were found on her body when it was recovered from the freezer - indicating she had been sleeping at the address when the killing took place, the court heard. She had moved in with Younis after leaving an abusive relationship and he had soon cut her off from her friends and family, the court heard. The prosecutor told jurors that there was little to no evidence that people in London who knew Henriett had seen her at all in , which the prosecutor told the jury suggested the defendant was skilled at separating women from their support networks.  Prosecutor Duncan Penny QC, said the last evidence of a sighting of Henriett was on August , , when both she and Younis were stopped together by police. Her face was covered, and diary entries attributed to Henriett suggest that she was alive and living with the defendant in late September that year. The same diary entries suggest that the defendant was violent towards her, and was controlling her, he told the jury. The court was told handwritten messages that had been torn up and left around the property were found by police after the womenaposs bodies were discivered. One of the notes appeared to refer to household rules banning Henriett from entering the kitchen and denying her food, jurors were told yesterday. She allegedly wrote of wanting to help and make herself useful around the house. The messages read: Every day go out get food and what I can bring to the house which is useful. Not allowed in the kitchen anymore. Boxer not gone give me food or anything from heaposs what is costing him extra money. Need to fix myself up to be normal.  Be straight, honest. No bulls***. Seat in one spot in heaposs house. Another of the notes said: When I admitted my sins, you judged and expelled me from the inner circle and planted poison in my broken heart that was anyway stone-cold by then. This poison has been tormenting and burning me. Iaposm afraid of dying and I donapost want to hate you!!! Itaposs hard to say goodbye, but itaposs no longer possible for me to remain and suffer, tolerating the hatred you display towards me. Henriettaposs blood was present on the carpets of the defendantaposs flat, the prosecution said. My Penny said of the diaries: Documents in the form of handwritten notes found at the defendantaposs address almost three years later seem to provide a clear picture of the existence of a controlling and abusive relationship involving Henriett and the defendant prior to her death. Most certainly, it would appear that Henriett felt dependent upon the defendant at that time and was keen to please him. The court also heard yesterday the accused killer told a WhatsApp group he wanted to get rid of a woman in his home before allegedly hiding Mihricanaposs body in the freezer.

You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA granddad who killed his three-month-old grandson after shaking him for around six seconds has been jailed for manslaughter. Wayne William Downing, , was looking after little Noah at a home in Perth, Australia, in May . Downing told police he had been asleep on the couch when Noah woke up in his room and began crying.Frustrated and tired, he said he gave the baby just a little shake, the Daily Star reports. A judge said Downing shook Noah in the irrational hope that aposdoing so would make him fall asleepapos. Downing shook Noah for between four and six seconds, causing traumatic injuries to his brain and spine. He reportedly said at the time that he could see the babyaposs head moving from side to side and backwards and forwards. As soon as I put him down I realised what Iaposd done... I was just trying to go off to sleep and to get some sleep. But Downing did not attempt to seek medical help after realising Noah was injured. When Noahaposs mum ed, she tragically found her babyaposs body cold and blue, it is reported. Downing only admitted to shaking the baby on his second interview with police, the Supreme Court of Western Australia heard. He was excessively tired and suffering from severe depression and anxiety at the time, the court was told. Justice Anthony Derrick accepted Downing loved Noah and had not intended to hurt or kill him. You shook Noah out of frustration, and in the irrational and forlorn hope that doing so would make him be quiet and fall asleep, he said.

title: dundee united aberdeen jim mclean new firm dave bowman
story: It’s one of the first fixtures in the Premiership calendar that Dundee United fans would have picked out.And Tangerines hero Dave Bowman believes the club’s ‘New Firm’ rivalry with Aberdeen ran deeper than most for iconic gaffer Jim McLean.The first top-flight clash between the sides since March  is pencilled in for October .The game will come nearly four decades on from an era in which they enjoyed success on the continent and regularly competed for domestic trophies with Old Firm duo Celtic and Rangers, often beating the Glasgow giants.With  miles separating United and the Dons, and because it isn’t a traditional rivalry, some didn’t take the fixture as seriously as the Dundee derby.However, Bowman insists McLean was hell-bent on emulating and exceeding Sir Alex Ferguson’s achievements, particularly in Europe.Sir Alex won several trophies during his time in the Granite City, including the Cup Winners’ Cup and Uefa Super Cup in .McLean’s Tangerines came close, losing the  European Cup semi-final to Roma and the Uefa Cup Final to IFK Gothenburg three years later.Bowman – player transition coach at Dundee United – believes the legendary boss became fixated with winning in Europe and lting an ultimately-elusive Scottish Cup.“He probably was and, for everything he did, it’s unbelievable he never won the Scottish Cup or went on to win something in Europe,” the -year-old said.“We got there that often in the Scottish and never won it. I was lucky enough to play under Ivanin  but I’d lost three before we’d managed to get one.“Jim was manager for a few before then as well so that was probably big thing for him, not being able to do the clean sweep of Scottish football.“Aberdeen were the benchmark, with the New Firm at the time, the two of us were competing against one another.“Them having won European titles probably was sore for him, especially having gone so close.“You look at Roma and then Gothenburg it was, obviously, a big thing for him.”Bowman, who would go on to make  appearances for the club, checked in at Tannadice in  and was part of United’s efforts to make the Uefa Cup showpiece that season.They, arguably, could go down in history as the club’s greatest-ever side.However, the former Hearts man was quick to hail McLean’s title-winning side of  as the best of all.“I would still say when they won the league in  was their best team, what an achievement that was for the club,” he added.“But he kept on evolving the team by bringing myself, Jim McInally and Iain Ferguson to the club in .“When I look back at my time, the players I played with were absolutely brilliant.“They were top professionals as well with the way they conducted themselves off the park. That’s probably why they got so much success.“The likes of Heggie , Davey , Eamonn , Luggy , Holtyand Maurice , they were all great.“For Jimmy Mac, Fergie and I to come into that, playing with them week-in, week-out, it certainly makes your football a lot easier to do.”Bowman looks back on their European adventures with great fondness, hailing the Arabs as some of the best supporters on the continent.“When you look back at the  Uefa Cup run and we were playing Lens in the first round, there wasn’t loads of press and fans but the hype grew as we went on,” he continued.“As we went through the rounds you could see it building.“The fans were brilliant. title: dundee united stevie frail micky mellon luke bolton
story: Dundee United’s new loan recruit Luke Bolton is in the running to face St Johnstone and can make an immediate impact.The Manchester City wide player finished the season with Luton Town in the English Championship four weeks ago but is considered to be match-ready.United assistant manager Stevie Frail feels Bolton is capable of hitting the ground running after his deal was confirmed yesterday.Frail said: “I think he was fit enough to feature last Saturday against Kilmarnockbut we just decided to give him a little bit of extra running after training.“The beginning of July was maybe his last game or session but, having watched training on Tuesday morning, he looked sharp.“Whether the manager looks to start him is another thing but he will be fit, ready and in contention for the game on Saturday.“He is quick, exciting and likes to run at people, so, hopefully, we have a player there who wants to go and play on this  and make a name for himself.”Bolton is unlikely to be the last new arrival at Tannadice, of course, with Frail adding: “I think the manager is maybe working on one or two things.“But we have the squad and he’s happy enough with what he has seen.“I think he knows we probably need to strengthen in certain areas but we have a full week to get the message across to start the game properly and get the three points.”Also in with an excellent chance of making Saturday’s team to take on the McDiarmid men is United captain Mark Reynolds, who sat out the final pre-season friendly against Killie due to a knock.Frail said: “We could have risked him last weekend and Mark probably wanted to be involved.#However, he knewhe played he could have made his injury slightly worse so we left him and he was fine on Tuesday.”Of course, Frail and his gaffer Micky Mellon are relatively new faces at the club too.The bond they formed as players together at Tranmere, though, is helping both get used to their new surroundings.Frail said: “I moved to Tranmere Rovers in  and Micky was already a player there.“To be honest, his was the first voice I heard when I walked into the club!“He was technically good, a box-to-box midfielder with plenty of energy and quality.“The friendship just grew from then. I was only there for two years but we have stayed in touch ever since.“The more that I worked with him, you could see he thinks about the game a lot.“Sometimes when you play, you do your own thing and go home. You don’t really think about the game.“But I think he studied it a wee bit more and I saw that the longer I was with him,# added the Tannadice number two.“His accent is still broader than mine and he has been down there for years.“Seriously, coming here is a great opportunity for me and I am delighted he gave me the call.“I actually spoke to Micky a lot and I met him just before lockdown, paying him a visit at Tranmere.“I knew his ideas and thoughts on the game and I was up here last week speaking to him as well.“I am getting to know what he wants. At times our ideas might dfer but his are the ideas that matter so it is up to me along with the rest of the guys to get that message onto the players as best we can.”LEE WILKIE: Coronavirus effect for Dundee United may be survival this season, then kick on in the next campaign" title"#LEE WILKIE: Coronavirus effect for Dundee United may be survival this season, then kick on in the next campaign# # Evening " src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp lee-wilkie-dundee-united-fc-micky-mellon embed # secretzkvLKPr" data-secret"zkvLKPr" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t t Month n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: george cran dundee fc
story: It’s oh so quiet at Dundee right now and I’m taking that as a good sign.There might be a cash crisis because of the coronavirus shutdown and the lack of income it brings.But there’s nothing rushed or frantic about the response to that at Dens Park right now.From the perspective of the club as a whole, that’s reassuring.From the inidual point of view of staff who may lose their jobs because of the cuts that have to be made, it’s anything but.After chopping their biggest bill in half for the next couple of months and then by a quarter until May – first-team wages – Dark Blues chiefs are now looking at other areas of the club.Unfortunately that means scaling back their youth setup.A setup which had been developing steadily over the past few years and we’ve begun to see players like Fin Robertson come through into the first team.Redundancy talks have begun with youth coaches and I can say from experience those discussions are anything but a walk in the park.Evenyou are fairly certain of the outcome, the stress that goes with that sort of situation is intense.The good news is the club know exactly what they’ve built with the academy and want to keep as much of the structure in place as they possibly can.How many coaches lose their jobs remains to be seen and I am incredibly sympathetic towards any that do.However, the new structure, evenscaled down, seems geared to ensure none of the kids are lost because of off-field matters.And that’s exactly where the emphasis should lie for an academy – the young players’ wellbeing coming first.The aim is to supplement the first team at Dens with talented youngsters but looking after the ones who don’t make it that far should also be high on the priority list.That’s what makes a youth set-up stand out from the rest – they’ll get great coaching and have a chance to be a pro footballer but eventhey don’t make it, it’ll be an enjoyable experience nonetheless.Evensome coaches are let go, and we’ll have to wait until the consultancy process is finished before we know, that someone with the experience of Gordon Strachan doing more coaching can only be a benefit.It’s obvious from being around the club over the past year or so that the former Scotland boss absolutely loves working with the youngsters at Dens, too.That’s certainly a silver lining on a dark cloud.Micky Mellon is right to ca’ canny on transfers at Dundee United right now.The start of the new Premiership season may be upon us but there’s still a long, long time until the transfer window closes.It does feel like the Tangerines aren’t splashing the cash like they might have done before the lockdown.That means Mellon is likely to only bring in maybe a couple more faces after securing Luke Bolton on loan from Man City yesterday.He’s also just getting to know his players and what they can give him.With only a handful of pre-season bounce games, it’s not always easy to know exactly what you need when the real action starts in the top flight.There may well be some surprises – I have to say Cammy Smith’s name popping up on the scoresheet at the weekend took me aback.After he departed for Dundalk, like most I thought his career at Tannadice was over.However, he’s got an opportunity now to prove himself again and say to the manager ‘I’m here, you don’t need to bring anyone  in’.Finally all the politicking and lawyer speak between Scottish clubs and theThe arbritration process has been hanging over the game like a bad smell.The whole palaver hasn’t done Scottish football a favour in any way. In fact, you can say that about the whole summer.Thankfully, this weekend we’re back to talking about controversy on the pitch instead – for the top flight clubs anyway.I’m delighted Dundee United fans will get to see their team in the Premiership this weekend, evenonly virtually.For Dundee fans, I feel your pain – the Championship kick off still feels a long way away.For as little as £. a month you can access all of our content, including Premium articles.Newsletter Get top stories straight to your inbox every day.SUBSCRIBE HERE!Latest blaize_config   n t t tCancelation Offer % - Web + ePaperGet unlimited access to the Eveningwebsite and Premium Content and all the benefits of the print paper in a digital replica of the Evening  n t t t t n t t t ua. per month  u recurring subscription n n t t t n t t t tEdition: n t t t tWeb + ePaper n t t t n t t t n t t t tDuration: n t t t t Month n t t t n t tSubscribe TodayEnjoy the digital edition of the Eveningnewspaper on your smartphone, tablet and computer.Unlimited access to all articles on the Eveningwebsite. title: nervous teachers and parents need more reassurance over return to school say unions
story: More needs to be done to reassure parents and teachers of a safeto school, according to union leaders.Both parents and staff will remain nervous about the full-timeto school from August  confirmed on Thursday, said Educational Institute of Scotland general secretary Larry Flanagan.He said extra teachers being employed with additional government funding could allow smaller classes and there must be proactive testing and rigorous distancing between staff and students.Warning against complacency, Mr Flanagan said: #The decision of the Scottish Government to reopen schools with a full pupilis predicated on the current successful suppression of the virus but as we are seeing in parts of Europe, that situation can change quite quickly.#Even with full implementation of the guidelines and its mitigations, many teachers and parents will be understandably nervous about ato the classroom.Many teachers and parents will be understandably nervous about ato the classroom.#Larry Flanagan, EIS#The EIS believes more could be done to reassure school communities around safetysmaller classes were introduced as the norm, employing the many unemployed teachers currently seeking work.#The additional funding announced is welcome, therefore, but this needs to translate into smaller class grouping to support physical distancing amongst pupils.#The union#s Fe spokesman, David Farmer, said he was disappointed the guidance failed to answer many questions.He said: #In certain areas of the advice where there was a need for crystal clarity, that#s not there.#There weren#t decisions taken about social distancing, for example, which seems to be a bit of a fudge.#He questioned the encouraging of distancing #where possible# for senior pupils.The total abandonment of social distancing in primary schools is something that for our members creates anxieties.#David Farmer, Fe EISHe said: #The whole idea of having social distancing in a normal-sized classroom with a teacher and  kids, forget that.#The total abandonment of social distancing in primary schools is something that for our members creates anxieties.#Former Harris Academy rector Jim Thewliss, who is general secretary of head teachers union School Leaders Scotland, said he was #more or less# content with the advice but that teachers would still have worries.He said: #The greatest concern I would expect from staff going back to school is around distancing and the way in which they engage with young people.#If you are in a profession where engagement is all, the way in which you conduct the relationship with a young person, the way you get them to learn, to say we want you to disengage, that in itself is going to be dficult, besides the fact there is a health implication to it.#The STUC urged the government and local authorities to heed teachers# advice to ensure schools were safe.Dave Moxham, general secretary, said: #Schools re-opening full-time is an enormous step which requires continuing suppression of the virus across communities, the full implementation of safety guidance and a proactive testing regime.Schools re-opening full-time is an enormous step.Dave Moxham, STUC#Despite the correct decision not to move into phase four, it is vital that we recognise that school re-opening coincides with a widerto work under phase three and that pressures on school and public transport must be carefully monitored.#Government and local authorities will need to listen carefully to staff across the whole school community as they strive to maintain a safe environment, allay the fears of pupils
